Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Dynamical Systems Approach to Shepherding and Sorting Microparticles in Fluids

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engineering problems requiring the controlled transport and positioning of solid particles suspended in fluids on a microscopic scale arise in contexts ranging from biomedical research to precision manufacturing. Technology enabling particle manipulation without direct mechanical contact between particles and manipulators is required in situations when the particles are fragile (like biological cells) or when high throughput is critical. This award supports fundamental research advancing a strategy whereby slender vibrating probes are used to excite patterns of flow in particle-laden fluids that in turn advect particles in desired ways. Preliminary results indicate that this approach can be used not only to achieve particle transport and positioning but also to separate particles according to physical attributes like size and geometry. The project requires coordinated activity by members of the research team in mathematical, computational, and experimental domains. Outcomes from this activity will include both scientific results with diverse practical implications and novel mechanisms for training undergraduate and graduate students across traditional disciplinary lines.

Technical issues to be addressed include the development of mathematical models with varying degrees of detail representing fluid flows near systems of vibrating probes, the development of approximate analytical models for the time-averaged dynamics of inertial particles advected by such flows, and the development of top-level control strategies for archetypical problems in particle transport and sorting. All of these will build upon successful preliminary studies by the project team and will be validated with numerical simulations exploiting high-fidelity computational models and with physical experiments exploiting a unique laboratory platform under development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching objective for this research program has been to advance techniques for simulating the contact-free manipulation of microparticles suspended in viscous streaming flows generated in a fluid by arrays of vibrating probes.

Intellectual merit: The principal challenge of predicting the transport of particles in viscous streaming flows is the wide disparity of time scales inherent in the problem. Particles in an oscillating fluid make only a small net motion in each oscillation cycle, so significant transport occurs only over thousands of such cycles. Nonetheless, the small oscillatory time scale is crucial to the larger mean time-scale motion. The previous computational framework required days-long simulations: slow, tedious simulations of the developing oscillating fluid flow and then the detailed trajectories, resolved at all time scales.

Under the current project, we have isolated the key physical principles at the heart of mean particle transport in streaming flows. By exploiting a combination of tools from asymptotics and generalized Lagrangian mean theory, we have developed a new framework that is around five orders of magnitude more computationally efficient, and thus, truly transformative to our ability to explore particle transport strategies. Streaming flows of one or multiple probes of arbitrary shape and motion can be simulated, and particle trajectories predicted, in a matter of minutes. We have used the tools to computationally explore some representative strategies.

Broader impact: The computational tools developed in this program have been made publically available in GitHub at https://github.com/jdeldre/ViscousStreaming.jl, with example notebooks that demonstrate their use in various scenarios. The framework is applicable to a wider range of problems, including particle transport in turbulent or in cardiovascular flows. The graduate student responsible for the work in this project has developed expertise in computational fluid dynamics and dynamical systems theory, and has had the opportunity to present his work at multiple scientific meetings.
